journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Dynamic response and stability of basalt woven fabric composites under impulsive compression

contrib-group.aff: College of Textiles, Key Laboratory of High-performance Fibers & Products, Ministry of Education, Donghua University, Shanghai, China

author-notes.corresp: Baozhong Sun, College of Textiles, Key Laboratory of High-performance Fibers & Products, Ministry of Education, Donghua University, Shanghai 201620, China. Email: sunbz@dhu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A modeling method is presented for the impulsive compression response of basalt woven fabric composites. Difference equations are used to describe the mechanical properties of basalt woven fabric composites in this model. These equations are obtained by experimental curves, and the result indicates that this method is suitable to describe the behaviors of basalt woven fabric composites at various strain rates. The frequency response and stability of basalt woven fabric composites under quasi-static and high strain rate compression have been analyzed and discussed in z-transform domain. The result shows that the magnitude and phase responses are very different in quasi-static loading from that in the high strain rate one. The basalt woven fabric composite system gradually turns stable with increasing strain rate. The model successfully fitted the impact response of basalt woven fabric composites.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The response of basalt woven fabric composites under impulsive loading is of interest in a large number of applications, such as a projectile impact on a composite armor. Understanding and characterizing the response of basalt woven fabric composites at a high strain rate are necessary for the efficient design of composite structures. The response at a high strain rate is more complex than that at the quasi-static one, so it is deferent to model to predict the dynamic response. Many researchers have studied the static mechanical properties on woven composites.1–3 Few researches have been investigated experimentally. Hosur et al.4 studied the compressive behavior of two-dimensional (2D) plain-woven fabric composites at strain rates 327, 436, and 544 s−1. There was a trend of increasing slope of the dynamic stress–strain curve as well as the peak stress for 2D plain-weave reinforced composite specimens. Hosur et al.5 also investigated stitched and unstitched woven carbon/epoxy laminates under high strain rate compression loading. The effects of unstitched/stitched configuration, fabric type, and loading directions on the compression properties were discussed. Sun et al.6 studied the compression properties of angle-interlock woven E-glass/vinyl ester composites under high strain rates. The stress–strain curves of the angle-interlock woven fabric composites under compression were strain-rate sensitive. The compression stiffness and the maximum compression stress increased linearly with the increase of strain rate. Dehkordi et al.7 investigated low-velocity impact behavior of laminates reinforced by basalt fabrics, as compared with nylon–basalt hybrid laminates, and suggested that their major energy absorption mechanism is fiber breakage, rather than delamination. Rosa et al.8 also studied post-impact mechanical characterization of basalt and glass woven fabric composites. The results showed that the materials have a damage tolerance that is similar to impact and also their post-impact residual properties after impact do not differ much, with a slight superiority for basalt fiber reinforced composites. However, these studies were all conducted in the time domain and not in the transform domain.

It is valuable to study the response of composites in the transform domain because both stress and strain at a high strain rate are transient and nonlinear. In this study, a model is presented for the dynamic compression response of basalt woven composites at various strain rates. In this model, the basalt woven composite is regarded as a discrete-time linear system and is characterized by a difference equation. According to the data tested at the quasi-static and high strain rates, the constant coefficients of the difference equation at every strain rate are evaluated and discussed. The z-transform was used to analyze the dynamic tensile response and stability of basalt woven fabric composites at various strain rates.

sec.title: Dynamic model of 3D woven composites based on discrete system theory
sec.p: In most applications, the discrete-time systems can be described by difference equations, which are equivalent, for the discrete-time domain, to differential equations for the continuous-time domain. In fact, the systems that can be specified by difference equations are powerful enough to cover most practical applications.8 So, the composites at the same strain rate can be regarded as a discrete-time system. In this system, the compression strain is regarded as input sequence and the compression stress as the output one. The input and output of the composites described by a linear difference equation at the same strain rate are generally related by9–12 (1)∑k=0Nbky(n-k)=∑r=0Marx(n-r) where x(n) and y(n) are, respectively, the input and output of the system and ar and bk the constants. The order of the discrete-time system is given by max (N, M), which is the order of the difference equation characterizing the system. According to actual needs, both N and M are 2 in this study. So, equation (1) can be rewritten (2)∑k=02bky(n-k)=∑r=02arx(n-r)
This equation can be interpreted as the compression stress y(n) being dependent both on samples of the input, x(n),x(n-1),x(n-2) and previous samples of the output y(n),y(n-1),y(n-2).
Applying the z-transform on both sides and using the linearity property, we find that (3)∑k=02bkZ{y(n-k)}=∑r=02arZ{x(n-r)}

Applying the time-shift theorem, we obtain (4)∑k=02bkz-kY(z)=∑r=02arz-rX(z) Therefore, for a linear system, given X(z), the z-transform representation of the input, and the coefficients of its difference equation, we can use equation (4) to find Y(z), the z-transform of the output. Applying the inverse z-transform relation, the output y(n) can be computed.

Making b0=1, without loss of generality, we can obtain the transfer function of the system (5)H(z)=a0+a1z-1+a2z-21+b1z-1+b2z-2 Making z=ejω, the frequency response of the system becomes (6)H(ejω)=a0+a1e-jω+a2e-2jω1+b1e-jω+b2e-2jω From equation (6), the magnitude and phase responses of H(ejω) can be obtained.

It is important to assess the stability of a discrete-time system, which represents the stability of the behavior of woven fabric composites at various strain rates in this article. A method to assess the stability is by determining whether the roots (the poles of the given transfer function) of a polynomial are inside the unit circle of the complex plane. If all poles of the given transfer function are inside the unit circle of the complex plane, the system is stable; if any pole is outside the unit circle, the system is unstable; and if the pole is on the unit circle, the system is critically stable. The MATLAB Signal Processing toolbox has a series of commands that are suitable for depicting the frequency response and the stability of the discrete-time system.

In the above, region of convergence (ROC) of the z-transform is not considered. This is because finite sequence is used in this article, whose ROC is |z|>0. It is to say that the ROC of the system includes z-plane except the origin, and so, ROC of the system is not considered.

sec.title: Materials and compression testing
sec.p: Table 1 lists the specifications of basalt woven fabrics used to manufacture composite samples. Figure 1 shows the surface photographs of basalt woven fabric. The fabrics were made of basalt filament tows, which were manufactured by Hengdian Group Shanghai Russia & Gold Basalt Fiber Co., Ltd. Vinyl ester resin (type RF-1001, manufactured by Shanghai Sino Composite Co., Ltd) was injected into the basalt woven fabric by vacuum-assisted resin transfer molding process and cured for 24 h at room temperature followed by post-curing in an oven at 80°C. The fiber volume of the basalt woven composite is 40% and its thickness 5.0 mm. The surface photograph and cross section of the composites are shown in Figures 2 and 3, respectively. The composite coupons were cut to give an in-plane dimensions of 9.0 × 9.0 mm2. Compression tests were conducted in the through-thickness direction for the basalt woven composites.

The quasi-static compression tests were conducted on an MTS 810.23 servo-hydraulic material tester with a constant crosshead speed of 1 mm/min. The strain rate corresponding to the speed approximates to 10−3 s−1. At least three composite coupons were tested and the average compression stress vs. strain curve was obtained. The high strain rate compression tests, at rates ranging from 8000 to 2700 s−1, were performed on a modified split Hopkinson pressure bar.12 Detailed information on compression testing could be found in Dehkordi et al.7

sec.title: Results and discussions
sec.p: If the strain (input) and stress (output) are known, we can evaluate the constant coefficient of the difference equation by the method of least squares according to the equations in ‘Dynamic model of 3D woven composites based on discrete system theory’. Then, applying these coefficients, we can easily obtain the frequency response of the basalt woven composite system and estimate the stability of the system.

sec.title: The difference equations of basalt woven composite system
sec.p:
According to the strain (input) and (output), the constant coefficient of the difference equation at each strain rate could be calculated with equations in ‘Dynamic model of 3D woven composites based on discrete system theory’ by the method of least squares. Table 1.
Main parameters of basalt woven fabric
Property 2D plain-woven composite
Reinforcement Plain basalt fabric
Fiber diameter (µm) 7
Warp number (Tex) 400
Weft number (Tex) 400
Warp density (ends/layer/10 cm) 60
Weft density (ends/layer/10 cm) 60
Layer number 9
Figure 1.
Surface photographs of basalt woven fabric.
Figure 2.
Surface photographs of basalt woven fabric composite.
Figure 3.
Cross section of basalt woven fabric composite.
For convenience, the difference equations at various strains in the matrix form are (7)[1111b(1)1b(2)1b(3)1b(4)1b(1)2b(2)2b(3)2b(4)2]·[y(n)y(n-1)y(n-2)]=[a(1)0a(2)0a(3)0a(4)0a(1)1a(2)1a(3)1a(4)1a(1)2a(2)2a(3)2a(4)2]·[x(n)x(n-1)x(n-2)] where the subscripts (1), (2), (3), and (4) represent, respectively, the strain rate 0.001, 800, 1500, and 2100 s−1. The difference equations at four kinds of strain rates are obtained as follows (8)[11110.0138-1.2571-1.2191-0.9662-0.94330.32050.36900.0426]·[y(n)y(n-1)y(n-2)] =[17.187353.923589.4387115.2641-8.6139-17.8648-24.4336-33.7434-6.4888-32.7427-50.7742-70.8399]·[x(n)x(n-1)x(n-2)]

The average of sum of squares due to error are, respectively, 0.2165, 0.5498, 0.7280, and 0.8775. From equation (8), it could be found that the strain coefficient along the column in the matrix increases or decreases with increasing strain rate. In other words, the strain coefficients of the difference equations regularly change with the increase of strain rate. In order to understand the change, the coefficients vs. strain rates are shown in Figure 4.

From Figure 4, it could be found that the coefficients ai(i=1,2,3) are almost linearly increased or decreased with increasing strain rate. The relationship between the coefficients and the strain rate could be linearly fitted with the following equation (9)a1=17.1030+0.0471ɛ· (R2=0.9992) (10)a2=-8.3386-0.0117ɛ· (R2=0.9914) (11)a3=-7.0374-0.0302ɛ· (R2=0.9977)

Equations (9) to (11) indicate that the coefficients ai(i=1,2,3) of the difference equations are correlative with the strain rates. Applying equations (9) to (11) to equation (8), it could be found that the effect of x(n),x(n-1),x(n-2) to the stress is bigger with increasing strain rate. This indicates that the historical strain plays an increasingly important part in the value of the stress of the composite with increasing strain rate. Figure 5 shows the experimental and simulative curves about the stress and strain. Figure 5 shows that the simulative curve is highly coincident with the experimental one. This indicates that the difference equation is suitable for describing the properties of the basalt woven fabric composites at various strain rates. From Figure 5, the compression stiffness (also called the dynamic elastic modulus of composite is the slope of the stress–strain curve at various strain rates), maximum stress, and failure strain have been obtained and listed in Table 2. It was found that the stiffness and maximum stress increase almost linearly with the strain rate and the failure strain decreases nonlinearly with the strain rate. These relationships could be fitted with following equation (12)E=0.0042ɛ·+2.7537 (R2=0.9975) (13)σmax=0.0401ɛ·+559.26 (R2=0.9797) (14)ɛfailure=19.328e-0.0007ɛ· (R2=0.9797)

If the maximum stress, compression stiffness and failure strain of the basalt woven composite is known according to equations (12) to (14), and assuming the coefficients of the difference equations of the basalt woven composite on the mechanical properties increase linearly with increasing strain rate, it is easy to predict the stress–strain curve at any strain rate. According to the three curves at strain rates 0.001, 800, and 2100 s−1, the relationship between the coefficients and strain rate could also be linearly fitted with increasing strain rate, and the result is almost same as equations (9) to (11). So, the curve simulated at a strain rate of 1500 s−1 in Figure 5 can be seen as the forecast curve using these equations. Figure 4.
Coefficients of the difference equations at various strain rates.
Figure 5.
Simulated and experimental compression results of basalt woven fabric composites.

sec.title: The frequency response of basalt woven composite system
sec.p:
The frequency response could be obtained with equations (6) and (9) to (11) at each strain rate.12 Figures 6 and 7 show the magnitude and phase responses, respectively. From Figure 6, it could be found that the amplitude of magnitude response decreases first, but increases soon afterwards, with the increase of normalized frequency under quasi-static compression. However, an inverse tendency occurs under high strain rate compression. Furthermore, the amplitude Table 2.
Mechanical properties of basalt woven composites in the through-thickness direction loading at various strain rates
Strain rate (s−1) Stiffness (GPa) Peak stress (MPa) Failure strain (%)
0.001 2.8612 563.44 20.860
800 6.0287 586.55 9.6513
1500 8.7838 615.19 6.2996
2100 11.7150 648.36 4.4418
Figure 6.
Magnitude response of basalt woven fabric composites at various strain rates.
Figure 7.
Phase response of basalt woven fabric composites at various strain rates.
Figure 8.
Pole locations of the transfer function for the basalt woven fabric composites at various strain rates: (a) 0.00 s−1; (b) 800 s−1; (c) 1500 s−1; and (d) 2100 s−1.
of the magnitude response at the same frequency increases with increasing strain rate. It indicates that the magnitude responses of the basalt woven fabric composite have many differences under quasi-static and high strain rate compression. From Figure 7, it could be found that the phase increases with increasing strain rate and the phase value is positive in most of the regions in quasi-static loading, while the phase in high strain rate loading is complex and the phase value negative in most of the regions. At the same frequency, the phase in quasi-static loading is greater than that in the high strain rate one. It indicates that the frequency response of the system is different at various strain rates.

sec.title: The stability of 3D woven composite system
sec.p: It is important to test the stability of basalt woven fabric composite because it is a structural material. When compressing the basalt woven composite, the woven structure will change and this will affect the stability of the composite material system under loading. Furthermore, the strain rate also affects the stability of the system. Figure 8 shows the location of the pole of the transfer function in z-plane for the basalt woven composite system at various strain rates. In Figure 8, it could be found that all poles of the transfer function are inside the unit circle of the complex plane. Consequently, the basalt woven composite system is stable from strain rate 0.00 to 2100 s−1. Furthermore, the pole with increasing strain rate is closer to the center of the unit circle of the complex. This indicates that the stability of the basalt woven fabric composite system gradually increases with strain rate. It can mainly be because of the fact that the compression damage at the quasi-static compression propagates slower than that in high strain loading and less flaws and defects control the failure of the material with increasing strain rate.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A dynamic model has been presented for the behavior of the basalt woven fabric composite under impulsive loading. The z-transform is then used to analyze the frequency response and system stability. The difference equations describing the dynamic response at various strain rates have been obtained and the result shows that the coefficients of the equations regularly change with the strain rate. The frequency response has been described including the magnitude and phase responses. The amplitude of the magnitude response first decreases, but increases soon afterwards, with the increase of the normalized frequency under quasi-static compression. However, there is an inverse tendency under high strain rate compression. Furthermore, the amplitude of the magnitude response increases with increasing strain rate at the same frequency. At the same frequency, the phase increases with increasing strain rate. The basalt woven fabric composite system gradually changes to stable with strain rate as a result of the composite’s internal structure and the testing strain rate.
